title: China Quiets Talk of Coronavirus Cover-Up in Wuhan
description: Demands for accountability run afoul of China’s nationalist narrative. A dozen countries, including Italy and India, began to relax lockdowns, and Israel all but declared victory.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow live updates on the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman and Maria Abi-Habib
title: Sewer Cleaners Wanted in Pakistan: Only Christians Need Apply.
description: In Pakistan, descendants of lower-caste Hindus who converted to Christianity centuries ago still find themselves marginalized, relegated to dirty jobs and grim fates.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — Before Jamshed Eric plunges deep below Karachi’s streets to clean out clogged sewers with his bare hands, he says a little prayer to Jesus to keep him safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenni Russell
title: The U.K. Needs a Real Government, Not Boris Johnson’s Puppet Cabinet
description: This prime minister has set his government up to fail. We can’t afford that right now.
content: LONDON — On the day a paler, thinner, notably less boisterous Boris Johnson returned to work after his near-death coronavirus experience, a Tory member of Parliament tweeted a GIF of a magnificent lion perched on a mountaintop, his mane blowing in the wind. “Good to see @BorisJohnson back at the helm!” he wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Make That 101: Cunningham Centennial Moves Online
description: Merce Cunningham’s centennial is over. But with theaters shuttered, recent performances will be available online.
content: Last year, dance companies around the world celebrated the centennial of Merce Cunningham’s birth by performing some of his vast repertory. Now, over the next few months, more than a dozen of those performances will be viewable online, the Cunningham Trust announced today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Desk Organizers
description: Working from home for who knows how long? Desk organizers are an easy way to bring order to the chaos of a makeshift work space.
content: When you’re working from home, the goal should be to “create an environment that’s positive and upbeat,” said Kelly Hoppen, a London-based interior designer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will McCarthy
title: Will Smoke From Controlled Burns Hurt Covid-19 Patients?
description: Monday: Officials are calculating risks ahead of fire season. Also: Beach closures were met with protest.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.6 Million in California
description: A condominium in a Victorian in San Francisco, a Spanish-style house in Los Angeles and an 1863 home in Mendocino.
content: A condominium in a Victorian in San Francisco, a Spanish-style house in Los Angeles and an 1863 home in Mendocino.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Solomon
title: Run 100 Miles, 100 Times, in 100 Weeks. Now in a Brooklyn Apartment.
description: With ultramarathons across the country canceled, Michael Ortiz has continued his quest to run 100 100-mile races in 100 consecutive weeks — on a treadmill.
content: The first time Michael Ortiz ran 100 miles inside his 960-square-foot Brooklyn apartment was the hardest. He laid out a roughly rectangular 40-foot cardboard track around the rugs on his living room floor and ran 13,200 laps on it. To save his knees from so many turns, Ortiz stopped every mile and reversed direction. “It wasn’t really running,” he said. “It was more like fast shuffling.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Warren Buffett Isn’t Buying Anything
description: Unlike his spending spree during the 2008 financial crisis, the Berkshire Hathaway chief is keeping his wallet closed.
content: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: An OLLA is a ceramic jar, often unglazed, used for cooking stews or soups, for the storage of water or dry foods, or for other purposes like garden irrigation. The Spanish word translates to “cooking pot.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: One Meat Plant. One Thousand Infections.
description: “I came to America thinking I could never go through hell.” After surviving civil war in Sudan, one of America’s most vulnerable workers faces the coronavirus.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bristow and Choire Sicha
title: Pictures From the Met Gala! (Yes, Last Year’s)
description: Look at all these people crammed so close together, wow.
content: It’s the first Monday in May, which means that civilization requires that oodles of celebrities assemble in outlandish clothing and, with their terror quite visible, slowly ascend the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for an unnaturally expensive dinner or perhaps human ritual sacrifice. Why? Because Anna Wintour, the artistic director of Condé Nast and editor of Vogue, compels them to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chantel Tattoli
title: Smash a Coronavirus Piñata. You’ll Feel Better.
description: Buy one or make one, then destroy it.
content: If you cannot join, beat. Such is the resolve of creative people bashing piñatas to defeat a pandemic (or at least, excise some of their feelings about it).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pogue
title: I Spent a Weekend Bingeing Airbnb’s Virtual Experiences. Was it Worth It?
description: While the rest of the country was binge-watching, David Pogue went binge-experiencing, cramming seven virtual Airbnb courses into a single weekend.
content: In the Great Lockdown, two-way video has become our primary social channel. Meetings, parties, concerts, music lessons, exercise classes: Any interactions that can be adapted to a Zoom video call, have been. Surely there’s nothing left to be Zoomified.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: How Not to Be a ‘Tiger King’
description: Please don’t steal the animals.
content: NASHVILLE — Once in the bluest of blue moons, the zeitgeist produces a cultural phenomenon so bizarre and so universally discussed as to be nearly inescapable. This spring, in the spirit of pet rocks, mood rings and streaking, Netflix launched “Tiger King,” a documentary series that landed online at the very moment a pandemic moved our lives online, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: A Family Business Survived One Pandemic. It’s Determined to Do It Again.
description: A small Buffalo manufacturer has had to trim its staff and spending. But its fourth-generation owner says: “We will take care of everybody.”
content: By the time Robert L. Stevenson gathered his work force at Eastman Machine in Buffalo in mid-March, businesses nationwide were shutting down. But Eastman, which makes fabric-cutting machines, has been in family hands for four generations, and Mr. Stevenson wasn’t about to turn off the lights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Jane Brody’s Guide to Life in Lockdown
description: I hope to offer some useful survival tips and help you realize that however distressed you may feel, you are neither abnormal nor alone.
content: Fear not, dear reader. I’m not about to tell you how much fun I’m having sheltering under the umbrella of Covid limitations, wondering whether the next unmasked person who passes too close to me on the street or in a store will transmit a deadly virus. But I hope to offer some useful survival tips and help you realize that however distressed you may feel, you are neither abnormal nor alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Watch This: The ‘Brockmire’ Finale
description: This week, our TV critic recommends the final episode of the show with TV’s lewdest banter, as well as another series about an emotionally damaged sports guy.
content: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, our TV critic Margaret Lyons offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Bearing With the Present While Recalling the Past
description: Parts of the country are starting to reopen even though the government is projecting a much higher death toll. Given this reality, who can think much about the future?
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Coronavirus, Italy, China: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Nice Thing for Spring
description: Pastel place mats and napkins add a bit of cheer to your dining room table.
content: For springtime and beyond, Hay, a Danish tableware and home furnishing company, has just introduced a line of tailored cotton place mats and napkins in pastel yellow, lavender, beige and gray, each trimmed with contrasting borders. The beige, for example, has sky blue trim. They come in sets of four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard M. Perloff
title: Four Students Were Killed in Ohio. America Was Never the Same.
description: The Kent State shootings marked the end of the 1960s, and the beginning of our era of political polarization.
content: On Friday, May 1, 1970, just after noon, about 300 students at Kent State University, outside Cleveland, gathered in the grassy campus Commons to protest President Nixon’s expansion of the Vietnam War into Cambodia. As part of the protest, they buried a copy of the Constitution, a symbol of their outrage that Congress had never formally declared war on Vietnam or Cambodia, and they announced another rally, set for May 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Spain Coronavirus Map and Case Count
description: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
content: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Victoria’s Secret Sale to Private Equity Firm Falls Apart
description: The agreement to sell a majority of the lingerie brand to Sycamore Partners was terminated after the firms sparred in court.
content: The plan to sell Victoria’s Secret to a private equity firm was mutually terminated on Monday after the buyer, Sycamore Partners, tried to back out of the deal because it said it did not agree with steps the lingerie brand took in response to the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas London
title: The Cloud Forming Over America’s Spies
description: A retired C.I.A. officer sees danger ahead for the independence and political impartiality of the 17 U.S. intelligence agencies if Trump’s choice for director of national intelligence is confirmed.
content: The appointment in February of Richard Grenell, a political operative and Donald Trump loyalist, as acting director of national intelligence after the renomination of former Congressman John Ratcliffe to permanently fill the position once he is confirmed, has many current and former intelligence professionals deeply concerned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Strassler
title: What We Lose When We Go From the Classroom to Zoom
description: Like other utopian dreams, the fiction of equality has its value.
content: When life was normal, my students and I gathered in classrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Athey, Michael Kremer, Christopher Snyder and Alex Tabarrok
title: In the Race for a Coronavirus Vaccine, We Must Go Big. Really, Really Big.
description: We should commit tens of billions toward a program.
content: The Covid-19 virus has killed over 200,000 people, overwhelmed health systems and confined billions of people in their homes. Large sections of the world economy have been locked down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gilbert Cruz
title: The Essential Stephen King
description: If you’ve never read his books, here’s where to start.
content: If you’ve never read his books, here’s where to start.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Books Have Literally Saved My Sanity’: Readers Respond to Our Letter to the Literary Community
description: Authors, publishing professionals and lifelong book-lovers across the world share their own experiences of reading during the pandemic.
content: Last month, editors at the Book Review wrote to our readers, expressing our concern for those whose livelihoods depend on books. Readers responded in droves, telling us how literature had helped them during this time of fear and instability, and sharing how they were supporting local bookstores and authors. One common theme: Books are a way to bring us together, even in these worrying times. Below are some of those responses, which have been edited and condensed for clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Per Olov Enquist, Literary Lion of Sweden, Dies at 85
description: His novels and plays used history to investigate life’s deeper questions. “One of the world’s most underrated great writers,” Kirkus Reviews once said.
content: Per Olov Enquist, an acclaimed Swedish novelist, playwright and journalist who for decades was a leading voice in Scandinavian literary and cultural life, died on April 25 in Vaxholm, Sweden, a village northeast of Stockholm. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Victoria’s Secret Sale to Private Equity Firm Falls Apart
description: The agreement to sell a majority of the lingerie brand to Sycamore Partners was terminated after the firms sparred in court.
content: The plan to sell Victoria’s Secret to a private equity firm was mutually terminated on Monday after the buyer, Sycamore Partners, tried to back out of the deal because it said it did not agree with steps the lingerie brand took in response to the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reducing Jail Populations
description: The Pew Charitable Trusts discusses policy changes involving public safety in Michigan. Also: Turkey’s response to the virus.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Don Shula, N.F.L. Coach Who Won, and Won, and Won, Dies at 90
description: He had more victories than any other coach in the league and the only perfect season in its history, all while helping to shape pro football’s modern era.
content: Don Shula, who won more games than any head coach in National Football League history, led the Miami Dolphins to the league’s only perfect season and helped usher pro football into its modern era, died on Monday in Florida. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Andrew Lack Is Out as the Head of NBC News After a Stormy Tenure
description: Rachel Maddow was among those at NBC who had put pressure on the news division’s leadership team.
content: The chairman of NBC News, Andrew Lack, will depart his role at the end of May, NBC Universal said on Monday, an abrupt end to the tenure of an executive whose tenacity and ability to withstand turmoil made for a long career in the fickle television news business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Billions Could Live in Extreme Heat Zones Within Decades, Study Finds
description: Researchers said that by 2070 extreme heat could encompass a much larger part of Africa, as well as parts of India, the Middle East, South America, Southeast Asia and Australia.
content: As the climate continues to warm over the next half-century, up to one-third of the world’s population is likely to live in areas that are considered unsuitably hot for humans, scientists said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beppe Severgnini
title: How Italy Coped, and Will Keep Coping
description: As Italians move toward a less stringent regimen to minimize their exposure to the coronavirus, they can take pride in an unusual collective effort.
content: CREMA, Italy — The first country outside Asia to experience the coronavirus pandemic on a large scale was Italy. It was the first to go into lockdown and impose a national quarantine, on March 9. And it is the part of Europe that suffered most. As of May 3, 29,000 people were known to have lost their lives because of Covid-19. The actual figures are likely to be higher, as they will be everywhere else. My northern region — Lombardy, Italy’s economic powerhouse — has registered half of the country’s deaths. Army truck convoys carried coffins to crematories around the country from Bergamo — where the death rate in March and April rose to more than four times what it was last year. Brescia, Lodi, Cremona and Crema — where I live — were also deeply affected. My hometown has been a ghost town for two months. People moaned but stayed at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Positive Coronavirus Tests Bring Scrutiny to German Soccer’s Reopening Plans
description: Germany’s closely watched Bundesliga confirmed 10 coronavirus cases in its first wave of mass testing. Government officials are expected to announce on Wednesday whether the league can restart.
content: LONDON — As one of the first major sports leagues to detail plans to return to action, Germany’s soccer league has become the bellwether for the thorny task of restarting sports events postponed by the coronavirus epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Money for Welfare Instead Funded Concerts, Lobbyists and Football Games, Audit Finds
description: According to a state audit, Mississippi allowed tens of millions of dollars in federal anti-poverty funds to be used in ways that did little or nothing to help the poor.
content: ATLANTA — The state of Mississippi allowed tens of millions of dollars in federal anti-poverty funds to be used in ways that did little or nothing to help the poor, with two nonprofit groups instead using the money on lobbyists, football tickets, religious concerts and fitness programs for state lawmakers, according to a scathing audit released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Kaplan
title: F.D.A. Orders Companies to Submit Antibody Test Data
description: The agency had come under fire from members of Congress and other groups for allowing dozens of wildly inaccurate tests to proliferate without oversight.
content: The Food and Drug Administration announced on Monday that companies selling coronavirus antibody tests must submit data proving accuracy within the next 10 days or face removal from the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: As Virus Deaths Jump, Boris Johnson’s Press Relations Turn Testy
description: A strain of populism, similar to that during the Brexit campaign, is visible in the government’s aggressive rebuttals and critiques of the news media.
content: LONDON — When Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced journalists last week for the first time since recovering from the coronavirus, he took his leadoff question from a member of the public, Michelle from Cornwall, who asked him about the dangers of infected tourists coming to her seaside region after the lockdown is lifted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.6 Million Homes in California
description: A condominium in a Victorian in San Francisco, a Spanish-style house in Los Angeles and an 1863 home in Mendocino.
content: This house, which now contains two residential units, was built in 1900 and recently renovated by Jeff Schlarb Design Studio. (Mr. Schlarb’s studio occupies the building’s ground-floor commercial space.) It is in the Presidio Heights neighborhood, within walking distance of well-known restaurants, the Sacramento Street Shopping District, known for its concentration of high-end design stores, and the Laurel Heights campus of the University of California, San Francisco. The Presidio, an 18th-century Spanish fort and the beloved outdoor space that surrounds it, is four blocks away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jolie Ruben and Amanda Webster
title: Remember Audiences?
description: Four photographers share their images of pre-quarantine crowds, when jamming together elbow to elbow felt so normal.
content: The photographer Jessica Lehrman specializes in getting deep into crowds — a lost luxury during the coronavirus quarantine. She’s been documenting Flatbush Zombies, a Brooklyn rap crew with a loyal community of fans, since 2012: “So many kids come to their shows having overcome suicide and depression and feeling alone and find community,” she said. “It’s beautiful.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Cavanagh
title: A New Line From a Dries Van Noten Alumna
description: After working for two of fashion’s most influential brands, the Belgian designer Meryll Rogge returned to her family farm to let her imagination run wild.
content: As a teenager living in rural Belgium in the late 1990s, Meryll Rogge, inspired in part by her love of European fashion magazines and the Canadian TV show “Fashion File,” wrote a list of the three designers she most wanted to work for later in life: Marc Jacobs, Dries Van Noten and Miuccia Prada. Since graduating from the prestigious fashion program at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp in 2005, Rogge, now 36, has checked off two of the three. After university, she moved to New York and worked with Jacobs for seven years, first as an intern and eventually as one of the lead women’s wear designers, before relocating to Antwerp and heading women’s wear design at Van Noten’s eponymous brand for three years. In 2019, when the time came to make her next move, rather than try for a hat trick, Rogge instead decided to found her own namesake label — not in Milan or New York or Antwerp but in a 19th-century Flemish barn nine miles southwest of Ghent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: How a New Breed of Union Activists Is Changing the Rules (and Newsrooms)
description: Cheered on by Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and others, a new generation is making gains on everything from layoff protections to gender-neutral pronouns. Can they help save the industry?
content: As the coronavirus crisis wreaked havoc in the news business last month, the newly installed president of the most prominent journalists’ union in the country, the NewsGuild, crossed a line that once seemed unimaginable: He asked the government for money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Become an Indoor Plant Parent
description: If you have a window, you can have plants. Just practice mindful watering.
content: Whether you want to grow a single trailing vine, a luscious leafy monstera, or some herbs, fruits or vegetables that you can use in your spring and summer cooking, this is the perfect time to get into indoor planting. Even if you don’t have a green thumb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Strugatz
title: How Will We Buy Our Perfume Now?
description: Sales are down leading up to this Mother’s Day, though candles and room sprays are doing OK. As some stores reopen, an industry ponders how to spritz safely.
content: The way fragrance is introduced, advertised and sold to the world hasn’t changed in nearly a century. No. 5, a seductive scent for the modern woman introduced by Coco Chanel in the 1920s, is marketed similarly to Tom Ford’s Black Orchid, a “modern” and “alluring potion” that came out in 2006. Both designers’ fragrances depend on an in-store experience that conjures these ideas and feelings through smell, somehow enticing people to spend over $100 on a bottle of scented water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: ESPN’s Live Sport Savior: Korean Baseball
description: ESPN will air six games a week to its sports-deprived audience, at least those who are night owls or early risers. Plus World’s Strongest Man at home, and bumps in the road for Australian rugby.
content: ESPN, in its desperate search for sports programming during the coronavirus pandemic, has been showing a wide range of events, from the acclaimed Michael Jordan documentary “The Last Dance” to “classic” basketball games, to, well, cup stacking and cherry-pit spitting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Your New Favorite Beans
description: Tejal Rao has an ace new recipe for Punjabi-style red beans, finished with cream, a few knobs of mozzarella, or even some coins of string cheese.
content: Good morning. It is the 125th day of the year, and you’d be forgiven for believing that you’ve spent the bulk of them inside this year, or the bulk of them at work, or both, or that you’ve been out of work that long, or that it’s possible time itself has become moot, a clock spinning without measure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Linda Yang, Who Offered Advice for Urban Gardeners, Dies at 83
description: Ms. Yang grew trees, flowers and herbs on a 19th-floor terrace. She was a contributor to The New York Times from 1979 until 1995.
content: Linda Yang, a gardening writer and author, died on April 20 at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: An Amazon Vice President Quit Over Firings of Employees Who Protested
description: Tim Bray, an engineer who had been a vice president of Amazon’s cloud computing arm, said the firings were “evidence of a vein of toxicity running through the company culture.”
content: A prominent engineer and vice president of Amazon’s cloud computing arm said on Monday that he had quit “in dismay” over the recent firings of workers who had raised questions about workplace safety during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Linda Yang, Who Offered Advice for Urban Gardeners, Dies at 83
description: Ms. Yang grew trees, flowers and herbs on a 19th-floor terrace. She was a contributor to The New York Times from 1979 until 1995.
content: Linda Yang, a gardening writer and author, died on April 20 at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: How Bailout Backlash and Moral Hazard Outrage Could Endanger the Economy
description: People are increasingly focusing not on preventing a depression but on which recipients of federal rescue are morally worthy.
content: The United States economy is in free fall, with tens of millions of people unemployed and countless businesses at risk of collapse. Congress has already allocated nearly $3 trillion to contain the crisis, and it is widely understood that it will need to do more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: China’s Coronavirus Vaccine Drive Empowers a Troubled Industry
description: By some measures, it is winning the race, with four companies already testing their vaccine candidates on humans.
content: China wants to beat the world in the race to find a coronavirus vaccine — and, by some measures, it is doing just that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Matt Flegenheimer
title: Both Parties Wonder: How Much Do Conventions Even Matter Anymore?
description: The coronavirus has prompted Democrats and Republicans to reconsider their summer gatherings. But even before that, a debate was playing out over whether they were a ritual from a time gone by.
content: Political conventions have been a balloons-and-bunting mainstay of American campaigns since the Republican Party gathered in Baltimore to nominate Henry Clay for president in 1831. But this year, they may join the list of crowded events — concerts, baseball games, movies and Broadway shows — forced off the stage because of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Too Cold for an Oil Cut? Russia’s Move Reveals a Long-Running Bluff
description: Moscow long rejected OPEC’s pleas to reduce output, citing its frosty climate as an excuse. Now, facing a glut, the country is closing wells, many in the Arctic.
content: MOSCOW — For most of the post-Soviet period, energy officials in Russia have resisted OPEC entreaties to participate in production cuts to help prop up oil prices, arguing that doing so was impossible because of the country’s cold climate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Sohn
title: When Can Child Care Resume?
description: The answer will depend on location, the age and health of caretakers, and everyone’s levels of acceptable risk.
content: I used to work for hours in a row without interruptions. Now, there is an astronaut-themed Lego set on my desk that seems to move a little bit each day. As I write this, my 7-year-old is sitting next to me, deconstructing pencils instead of doing his schoolwork. In listening to an interview I had recorded, I heard a young voice in the background and then heard myself say, “I’ll help you in a second. I’m still on the phone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Hurlburt
title: The World Is Helping Americans Who Don’t Always See It
description: Cities and states are using international support to cope. They need to plan for global partnership to recover.
content: It’s hard to imagine that 97 percent of Americans could agree on anything right now. But that is how many told Pew Research they either strongly (86 percent) or somewhat (11 percent) support international cooperation to fight infectious disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: Live From D.C., It’s the Supreme Court!
description: The court heard oral arguments remotely, and broadcast the audio live, for the first time Monday. It was a spectacle made for the radio age.
content: “Justice Sotomayor? … Justice Sotomayor?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Axelrod and David Plouffe
title: What Joe Biden Needs to Do to Beat Trump
description: To win, he has to find a way to get beyond the basement tapes and project himself into our ever more digital world.
content: Joe Biden’s most memorable moments on the campaign trail have come through spontaneous, intensely moving encounters with people who, like Mr. Biden, have endured searing struggle and loss. His authentic sense of empathy is a quality uniquely suited to this agonizing moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Thomas Fuller
title: Why Liberal Californians Don’t Want to Go Back to Normal
description: California has let thousands of people out of prisons and found shelter for many who had been living on the streets, but how far the progressive wing can push the state remains a question.
content: LOS ANGELES — Housing for those who are homeless. Criminal justice reform. Addressing the digital divide for schoolchildren in rural areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Streaming Plays Give Big-Name Actors a Chance to Give Back
description: “Spotlight on Plays,” featuring John Malkovich, Patti LuPone, Sally Field, Bryan Cranston and others, will aid the Actors Fund.
content: It doesn’t look like Broadway is going to reopen any time soon. So one producer has decided to start making shows online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: YoungBoy Never Broke Again Earns a Second No. 1 Album in 7 Months
description: “38 Baby 2,” the rapper’s latest mixtape, opened with considerably lower numbers than his last top seller in a slow week on the charts.
content: Back in October, YoungBoy Never Broke Again, a 20-year-old Louisiana rapper with a big following on YouTube, topped the Billboard album chart for the first time. Now, just seven months later — and still at age 20 — he is back with another No. 1 release, even though his numbers have slipped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: An Amazon Vice President Quit Over Firings of Employees Who Protested
description: Tim Bray, an engineer who had been a vice president of Amazon’s cloud computing arm, said the firings were “evidence of a vein of toxicity running through the company culture.”
content: A prominent engineer and vice president of Amazon’s cloud computing arm said on Monday that he had quit “in dismay” over the recent firings of workers who had raised questions about workplace safety during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Become an Indoor Plant Parent
description: If you have a window, you can have plants. Just practice mindful watering.
content: Whether you want to grow a single trailing vine, a luscious leafy monstera, or some herbs, fruits or vegetables that you can use in your spring and summer cooking, this is the perfect time to get into indoor planting. Even if you don’t have a green thumb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: For Joanna Gaines, Home Is the Heart of a Food and Design Empire
description: She and her husband, Chip, the co-stars of “Fixer Upper,” have married Texas tradition with modern taste to create a wildly popular brand.
content: The first Chip Gaines heard of avocado toast was in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: The Ghost Dogs of the Amazon Get a Bit Less Mysterious
description: Scientists have produced data that shows the range of an enigmatic short-eared canid species that has yet to be widely studied.
content: It is one of the Amazon rain forest’s most elusive and enigmatic mammals. Experts call the species “shy” or even “a ghost.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang, Amy Qin and Sui-Lee Wee
title: Coronavirus Survivors Want Answers, and China Is Silencing Them
description: In Wuhan, where the pandemic started, the police have threatened and interrogated grieving relatives. Lawyers have been warned not to help them sue.
content: The text messages to the Chinese activist streamed in from ordinary Wuhan residents, making the same extraordinary request: Help me sue the Chinese government. One said his mother had died from the coronavirus after being turned away from multiple hospitals. Another said her father-in-law had died in quarantine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Cavanagh
title: A New Line From a Dries Van Noten Alumna
description: After working for two of fashion’s most influential brands, the Belgian designer Meryll Rogge returned to her family farm to let her imagination run wild.
content: As a teenager living in rural Belgium in the late 1990s, Meryll Rogge, inspired in part by her love of European fashion magazines and the Canadian TV show “Fashion File,” wrote a list of the three designers she most wanted to work for later in life: Marc Jacobs, Dries Van Noten and Miuccia Prada. Since graduating from the prestigious fashion program at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp in 2005, Rogge, now 36, has checked off two of the three. After university, she moved to New York and worked with Jacobs for seven years, first as an intern and eventually as one of the lead women’s wear designers, before relocating to Antwerp and heading women’s wear design at Van Noten’s eponymous brand for three years. In 2019, when the time came to make her next move, rather than try for a hat trick, Rogge instead decided to found her own namesake label — not in Milan or New York or Antwerp but in a 19th-century Flemish barn nine miles southwest of Ghent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: How a New Breed of Union Activists Is Changing the Rules (and Newsrooms)
description: Cheered on by Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and others, a new generation is making gains on everything from layoff protections to gender-neutral pronouns. Can they help save the industry?
content: As the coronavirus crisis wreaked havoc in the news business last month, the newly installed president of the most prominent journalists’ union in the country, the NewsGuild, crossed a line that once seemed unimaginable: He asked the government for money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple
title: As World Comes to Halt Amid Pandemic, So Do Migrants
description: Laborers have not just stopped traveling in search of work. Many have also headed back to their home countries.
content: MEXICO CITY — A migrant shelter in southern Mexico called La 72 has for years been a popular way station for those traveling from Central America to the United States. Last year it received a record number of visitors, sometimes sheltering more than 2,000 a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Too Cold for an Oil Cut? Russia’s Move Reveals a Long-Running Bluff
description: Moscow long rejected OPEC’s pleas to reduce output, citing its frosty climate as an excuse. Now, facing a glut, the country is closing wells, many in the Arctic.
content: MOSCOW — For most of the post-Soviet period, energy officials in Russia have resisted OPEC entreaties to participate in production cuts to help prop up oil prices, arguing that doing so was impossible because of the country’s cold climate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Lara Jakes
title: World Leaders Join to Pledge $8 Billion for Vaccine as U.S. Goes It Alone
description: The E.U. organized a teleconference to raise money for coronavirus vaccine research, drawing contributions from around the world.
content: BRUSSELS — Prime ministers, a king, a prince and Madonna all chipped in to an $8 billion pot to fund a coronavirus vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: The New York Times, Anchorage Daily News and ProPublica Win Pulitzers
description: The Pulitzer board makes The Times a winner in three categories. The Anchorage Daily News and ProPublica take a major prize at a time when local journalism is in crisis.
content: Pulitzer Prizes were awarded on Monday to news organizations that delved into corruption, law enforcement and the legacy of racism in the United States, recognizing journalists’ examinations of inequality and other societal ills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Hope and Worry Mingle as Countries Relax Coronavirus Lockdowns
description: At least a dozen countries pulled back on restrictions put in place to combat the virus. But leaders warned that an uptick in infections could shut life down again.
content: ROME — Wearing a Plexiglas visor, large white mask and blue rubber gloves, Catia Gabrielli looked ready for whatever could come her way on Monday as Italy tentatively loosened some of its strictest lockdown provisions against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: 3 Hospital Workers Gave Out Masks. Weeks Later, They All Were Dead.
description: The coronavirus has taken a steep toll on the often-invisible army of employees who keep New York hospitals running.
content: They did not treat patients, but Wayne Edwards, Derik Braswell and Priscilla Carrow held some of the most vital jobs at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Biden Camp Finds Selling Point in Ailing Economy: His Work on 2009 Recovery
description: He oversaw the rollout of a $787 billion stimulus package. His campaign may leverage that as the coronavirus pandemic and economic collapse dominate the conversation.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. had just been sworn in as vice president. All he needed now was a job.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: Latest Updates
description: New York and six other states are banding together to purchase and allocate the medical equipment needed to battle the coronavirus.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 5 Premiere Recap: Chopping Heads
description: Chuck scrambles to save his family as Bobby and Wags look to cut down a charismatic new threat.
content: Move over, Bobby Axelrod: You’re not the only pugnacious redhead in Axe Cap’s hallowed halls anymore.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 4, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, May 4, 2020.
content: Because of a production error, a cover article on Saturday about the effects of the coronavirus on the production of oil in the Permian Basin included columns of type that were out of order.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For New York’s Therapists, Steering Relentless Waves of External and Internal Angst
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 4, 2020.
content: “We are doing everything and anything to help each other and our patients to get through this. Sometimes, that’s crying together.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: creche
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Politics: Biden Speaks on an Allegation
description: A candidate issues a denial, and Congress considers a return: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: President Trump at the White House on Sunday after spending a few days at Camp David.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Working From Home, Celebrities Grapple With Revealing Too Much
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda makes sure that pictures of his children are shielded from public view, and Marilu Henner says fans should never get a glimpse of a bathroom.
content: Lin-Manuel Miranda seems to be everywhere these days: riffing on the term “OK, Boomer” for Conan O’Brien on “Conan”; belting out “Hamilton” ballads for Jimmy Fallon on “The Tonight Show”; even singing “Old McDonald Had a Farm” for “Elmo and Friends” on a special Covid-19-focused “Sesame Street.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Steinhauer
title: For Artists in Need, a New Coalition Brings $11.6 Million in Speedy Relief
description: It’s only a bridge, groups warn. A survey shows nearly 62 percent of artists responding have become fully unemployed because of the pandemic.
content: Anne Finger is a writer of fiction and nonfiction who, like many others in her field, can’t rely on income from her creative work alone. A polio survivor and wheelchair user, Ms. Finger bought her loft in Oakland, Calif., 22 years ago with the idea that it would serve as a steady financial source. She rents out the space for photo and video shoots and also began listing her son’s former bedroom on Airbnb once he moved out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: ‘Westworld’ and ‘Devs’ Asked Big Questions. A Physicist Responds.
description: This season’s most ambitious sci-fi series took on the same philosophical conundrum: Is free will an illusion? The theoretical physicist Sean Carroll digs into the nature of our reality.
content: After we’ve made a decision, to stay home rather than go to a dinner party, say, or to profess our love to someone, we ruminate over what we imagine as equally plausible alternative outcomes. Would we be happier if we had decided to go to the party? Would we regret not having shared how we feel?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Vaccine Race, U.S.-China Tensions, Travel Bubble: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Be a New Orleanian Wherever You Are
description: Commander’s Palace in New Orleans now ships meals for two or four nationwide.
content: You’ll need to assemble your own jazz band or find a playlist on Spotify to do justice to a Commander’s Palace dinner at home, especially for Mother’s Day. For the first time, the legendary New Orleans restaurant, in business since 1893, is serving a limited menu for delivery, shipped frozen and nationwide through Goldbelly. The menu offers a three-course dinner for two ($179) or four ($299), with turtle soup, garlic bread, sweet and spicy quail, and pecan pie. À la carte options, serving two or four, are also available. Though the soup just takes a reheat once it’s thawed, for the quail you’ll have to channel your inner Paul Prudhomme and Emeril Lagasse — the birds come raw with the ingredients and instructions for stuffing, glazing and roasting them. All the items in the package can be refrigerated for a couple of days, so you have wiggle room in terms of timing. They send an entire pecan pie regardless of the order. There is a limited number of orders filled each day, and delivery is usually about two days from when the order is placed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Fire Up Your Laptop: A Curated Guide to Theater Now Online
description: Watch as the virtual curtains rise, from “Acquanetta” to the Wooster Group, with stops at Shakespeare and “Fun Home.”
content: When Broadway closed on March 12, it was only the tip of the iceberg: live theater has since suspended operations around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd Heisler
title: 15 Funerals a Day: The Pace of Death Stuns Brooklyn Muslims
description: Al-Rayaan Muslim Funeral Services has turned to family members and fellow mourners to offer prayers and move bodies.
content: All day long, wood coffins are carried in and out of Al-Rayaan Muslim Funeral Services in Brooklyn. What is meant to be a peaceful, reflective moment for grieving families has given way to a chaotic rhythm. Workers climb into a refrigerated truck and carefully carry the dead into the funeral home for a prayer, then back out to be transported to their final resting place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: After 301 Days in Egyptian Prison, an American Teacher Flies Home
description: Under pressure from the Trump administration, Egypt released Reem Desouky, an arts teacher from Pennsylvania who was jailed over a Facebook page critical of the country’s authoritarian president.
content: CAIRO — An American woman held without trial in an Egyptian prison for more than 300 days, over a Facebook page that criticized Egypt’s president, has been freed and returned to the United States, her supporters and American officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yoojin Na
title: Do Not Resuscitate
description: We need to be honest with ourselves and our patients. We can’t “do everything” and “save everyone.”
content: “We are in middle of a pandemic. The decision you make is not just about your family member,” I yelled into the phone. It was the only way I could be heard through my respirator helmet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Fire Up Your Laptop: A Curated Guide to Theater Now Online
description: Watch as the virtual curtains rise, from “Acquanetta” to the Wooster Group, with stops at Shakespeare and “Fun Home.”

content: CAIRO — An American woman held without trial in an Egyptian prison for more than 300 days, over a Facebook page that criticized Egypt’s president, has been freed and returned to the United States, her supporters and American officials said on Monday.

For the first time, the legendary New Orleans restaurant, in business since 1893, is serving a limited menu for delivery, shipped frozen and nationwide through Goldbelly. author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Almar Latour Is Named Chief Executive of Dow Jones
description: Mr. Latour will also become the publisher of The Wall Street Journal when he assumes his new position on May 15, the company said.
content: Almar Latour has been appointed publisher of The Wall Street Journal and chief executive of its parent company, Dow Jones, the company announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Daniel and Valerie Zane, Married 71 Years, Die 2 Days Apart
description: Both in their 90s, they lived together in a senior facility; he took care of his wife, who was in declining health. Then he got the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd Heisler
title: 15 Funerals a Day: The Pace of Death Stuns Brooklyn Muslims
description: Al-Rayaan Muslim Funeral Services has turned to family members and fellow mourners to offer prayers and move bodies.
content: All day long, wood coffins are carried in and out of Al-Rayaan Muslim Funeral Services in Brooklyn. What is meant to be a peaceful, reflective moment for grieving families has given way to a chaotic rhythm. Workers climb into a refrigerated truck and carefully carry the dead into the funeral home for a prayer, then back out to be transported to their final resting place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Body of Fifth Amish Child Is Found After Buggy Accident
description: The family was holding a funeral service for four children who died last week when news arrived that the fifth had been found.
content: An Amish family was holding a funeral service on Saturday for four of their children who died in a buggy accident in northeastern Kentucky when authorities arrived with news: The body of a fifth child in the accident, missing for days, had just been found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Julian E. Barnes
title: Trump Ally Sees Easier Path to Intelligence Post in Second Attempt
description: Representative John Ratcliffe, an outspoken defender of President Trump, still faces questions about his partisanship and qualifications to be director of national intelligence.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump first picked Representative John Ratcliffe of Texas to be the nation’s intelligence chief last summer, but resistance in the Republican Senate was so firm that Mr. Ratcliffe’s name was withdrawn before his nomination ever became official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Stephenie Meyer to Publish a New ‘Twilight’ Book, ‘Midnight Sun’
description: The author of the popular “Twilight” vampire series announced that the new book, told from the vampire Edward Cullen’s perspective, will go on sale Aug. 4.
content: Fans of Edward Cullen, the brooding vampire hero from Stephenie Meyer’s best-selling “Twilight” series, will have something fresh to bite into this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Coronavirus, ‘Murder Hornets,’ Star Wars Day: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Washington, D.C., has become one of the new hot spots for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Almar Latour Is Named Chief Executive of Dow Jones
description: Mr. Latour will also become the publisher of The Wall Street Journal when he assumes his new position on May 15, the company said.
content: Almar Latour has been appointed publisher of The Wall Street Journal and chief executive of its parent company, Dow Jones, the company announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Jerry Seinfeld Is Making Peace With Nothing: He’s ‘Post-Show Business’
description: In a wide-ranging interview from his home quarantine, the comedian says his new Netflix special may be his last. Still, he is optimistic about the return of live comedy after the pandemic.
content: Many of us have been wondering lately what Jerry Seinfeld, the sitcom character, would be doing in this current era of home quarantines and social distancing: how his extreme fastidiousness, self-centeredness and constant scrutiny of quotidian details (not to mention the hyperbolic traits of his fictional friends and neighbors) would be stretched to hilarious extremes in an environment of isolation and anxiety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yoojin Na
title: Do Not Resuscitate
description: We need to be honest with ourselves and our patients. We can’t “do everything” and “save everyone.”
content: “We are in middle of a pandemic. The decision you make is not just about your family member,” I yelled into the phone. It was the only way I could be heard through my respirator helmet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: J. Crew Didn’t Need to Live Forever
description: The company has filed for bankruptcy protection and is restructuring. It also lost its way creatively.
content: Anyone wondering how J. Crew’s fashion fairy tale came to such a crashing halt this week, as the company became the first retailer to declare Chapter 11 bankruptcy during the new coronavirus pandemic, need look no further than its own home page. Featuring an attractive cast of windswept young men and women in various nautical stripes and florals on a sailboat off the coast of some New England town, it declares: “Blue skies ahead …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaclyn Peiser
title: The New York Times Won 3 Pulitzers. Read the Winning Work.
description: The Times won in the categories of commentary, investigative journalism and international reporting.
content: The New York Times won three Pulitzer Prizes on Monday, bringing the publication’s total to 130 since Columbia University began presenting the annual journalism award in 1917.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Newspaper’s Top Editor Is Now a ‘Homeless’ Blogger
description: A 54-year-old journalist lost his job running an Indiana newspaper, as well as the apartment that went with it. He moved to a Motel 6.
content: On Wednesday he was laid off. On Friday he was living in a Motel 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Pulitzer Prize: 2020 Winners List
description: From reporting on sexual violence in Alaska to Boeing’s missteps after the 737 Max crashes, here is the full list of winners and finalists.
content: The Anchorage Daily News, in collaboration with the nonprofit outlet ProPublica, won the prestigious public service award for a yearlong investigation of sexual violence in Alaska. The series, led by the reporter Kyle Hopkins, uncovered a “two-tiered” criminal justice system in the state, in which rural communities, disproportionately populated by Indigenous people, had limited or no access to law enforcement and four times as many sex offenders as other areas in the United States, per capita.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Hears First Arguments via Phone
description: The conference call started with the usual Oyez! chant, but that was almost the only traditional thing about the arguments in a trademark case.
content: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. played traffic cop. Justice Clarence Thomas asked his first questions in more than a year. Justice Sonia Sotomayor disappeared for a few moments, apparently having failed to unmute her phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Virus Deaths, Migration, Disney: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Daniel and Valerie Zane, Married 71 Years, Die 2 Days Apart
description: Both in their 90s, they lived together in a senior facility; he took care of his wife, who was in declining health. Then he got the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: How to Cook and Freeze a Large Piece of Meat, and Eat for Weeks
description: A large, inexpensive roast is a boon for busy home cooks: Prepare it simply, then let it star in a number of fast weeknight meals. J. Kenji López-Alt explains.
content: On my last bimonthly trip to the supermarket to stock up on staples, I noticed the beef offerings had transitioned from mostly steaks and chops to large, inexpensive roasts like top round, eye rounds and tri-tip. This makes sense, given our slowed shopping cadence. But what’s the best way to deal with big, inexpensive cuts of beef?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Maj Sjowall, Godmother of Nordic Noir, Dies at 84
description: With her companion, Per Wahloo, Ms. Sjowall wrote 10 books starring Martin Beck, a laconic, flawed Swedish detective.
content: Maj Sjowall, a Swedish novelist who collaborated with her companion on a series of celebrated police procedurals that heralded the crime-fiction genre of Nordic Noir (including the wildly successful books of Stieg Larsson), died on Wednesday in a hospital in Landskrona, Sweden. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: They Survived the Holocaust. Now They’re Confronting the Virus.
description: The generation that endured Nazi death camps is especially vulnerable to the pandemic.
content: One got out of Nazi Germany on a Kindertransport train to Sweden, never again seeing his parents, who were exterminated in the death camps. One survived two notorious concentration camps, Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, and was discovered by British troops on a pile of bodies, half-dead with typhus. One endured freezing temperatures and near starvation in a slave-labor camp in Siberia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Westworld’ Season 3 Finale Recap: Choosing Beauty
description: Turns out Dolores never stopped seeing the good side of humanity. She just had a funny way of showing it.
content: The end of David Fincher’s 1999 provocation “Fight Club” and the end of this week’s Season 3 finale of “Westworld” are essentially the same moment, one mapped onto the other like a Dolores pearl dropped into another host’s body. After a revolution deliberately premised on bringing anarchy to a well-ordered, antiseptic world, a man and a woman can only watch helplessly as the bombs detonate in high rises and chaos engulfs the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Cuba?
description: Can you find Cuba on a map? What else do you know about this Caribbean nation with a population of about 11.3 million people?
content: Can you find Cuba on a map? What else do you know about this Caribbean nation with a population of about 11.3 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York Looks Toward Restarting; New Jersey Will Keep Schools Closed
description: Governor Cuomo said 226 more people had died of the coronavirus in New York, the lowest one-day total in five weeks.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday provided new details about the process that New York plans to follow for reopening as the coronavirus continues to decline in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: New Mexico Invokes Riot Law to Control Virus Near Navajo Nation
description: The lockdown in Gallup, on the edge of the country’s largest Indian reservation, comes in response to a worsening outbreak.
content: GALLUP, N.M. — All the roads into this city on the edge of the Navajo Nation are closed. The soldiers at the checkpoints have their orders: Outsiders must turn around and drive away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump and His Infallible Advisers
description: Beware men who never admit having been wrong.
content: “You have 15 people, and the 15 within a couple of days is going to be down close to zero.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Maj Sjowall, Godmother of Nordic Noir, Dies at 84
description: With her companion, Per Wahloo, Ms. Sjowall wrote 10 books starring Martin Beck, a laconic, flawed Swedish detective.
content: Maj Sjowall, a Swedish novelist who collaborated with her companion on a series of celebrated police procedurals that heralded the crime-fiction genre of Nordic Noir (including the wildly successful books of Stieg Larsson), died on Wednesday in a hospital in Landskrona, Sweden. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Farmer to Restaurants Now Delivers
description: The Chef’s Garden in Ohio has opened its vegetable sales to home cooks.
content: For decades, the Chef’s Garden, a 350-acre farm in Huron, Ohio, has been a source of first-rate produce for restaurants across the country. Now the hundreds of items it cultivates are available for home delivery. What makes the offerings so compelling to the discerning cook is not just the dazzling seasonal variety — including sultry purple asparagus, glossy little squashes and bundles of frilly braising greens — but its utter freshness. And when it comes to some items like lettuces, just-picked freshness makes a huge difference. The vegetables look and taste better and even last longer in your fridge. There are assorted produce boxes containing the farm’s choices starting at $59, or you can assemble your own item by item.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Hill, Jacob Grumbach, Adam Bonica and Hakeem Jefferson
title: We Should Never Have to Vote in Person Again
description: Our new paper shows vote-by-mail dramatically boosted Colorado’s turnout. It could change this fall’s election and every election after.
content: As the coronavirus continues to spread throughout the country, there are growing concerns about whether in-person voting can be conducted safely in the months ahead, including for the November presidential election. A huge expansion of mail voting is one way to ensure that participating in democracy won’t undermine public health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: They Survived the Holocaust. Now They’re Confronting the Virus.
description: The generation that endured Nazi death camps is especially vulnerable to the pandemic.
content: One got out of Nazi Germany on a Kindertransport train to Sweden, never again seeing his parents, who were exterminated in the death camps. One survived two notorious concentration camps, Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, and was discovered by British troops on a pile of bodies, half-dead with typhus. One endured freezing temperatures and near starvation in a slave-labor camp in Siberia.

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: How to Cook and Freeze a Large Piece of Meat, and Eat for Weeks
description: A large, inexpensive roast is a boon for busy home cooks: Prepare it simply, then let it star in a number of fast weeknight meals. J. Kenji López-Alt explains.
content: On my last bimonthly trip to the supermarket to stock up on staples, I noticed the beef offerings had transitioned from mostly steaks and chops to large, inexpensive roasts like top round, eye rounds and tri-tip. This makes sense, given our slowed shopping cadence. But what’s the best way to deal with big, inexpensive cuts of beef?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Bremmer, Cliff Kupchan and Scott Rosenstein
title: Coronavirus and the Sweden Myth
description: The country’s approach to the pandemic sets a seductive example. But the United States shouldn’t copy it.
content: For countries battling the coronavirus pandemic, Sweden sets a seductive example. While the world’s biggest economies have shut down, one small, well-governed Scandinavian country has allowed most businesses to stay open. The strategy apparently relies on “herd immunity,” in which a critical mass of infection occurs in lower-risk populations that ultimately thwarts transmission.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Models Project Sharp Rise in Deaths as States Reopen
description: An internal Trump administration report expects about 200,000 daily cases by June. The White House bars coronavirus task force officials from testifying to Congress without approval.
content: As President Trump presses for states to reopen their economies, his administration is privately projecting a steady rise in the number of coronavirus cases and deaths over the next several weeks. The daily death toll will reach about 3,000 on June 1, according to an internal document obtained by The New York Times, a 70 percent increase from the current number of about 1,750.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: For Disney, a Stricken Empire
description: The entertainment conglomerate’s vastness, once its strength, has posed a challenge during the pandemic.
content: LOS ANGELES — It was once a prospering kingdom, the envy of all the land. But in crept an invisible menace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Carnival Plans to Sail Again in August, Maybe
description: The company’s flagship line said eight of its ships could begin cruising on Aug. 1, though it later said “there is no assurance” it would start sailing again on that date.
content: The Carnival Corporation, the giant cruise company widely criticized for its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, announced on Monday that some of its ships may begin sailing again as soon as August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: The Bang on a Can Marathon, Still Lovably Scruffy Online
description: The six-hour event, which approximated what our critic cherishes about going to live performances, will have a follow-up on June 14.
content: With the performing arts landscape ravaged by the coronavirus pandemic, a new online ecosystem has risen — temporarily, we hope — in its place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘“Murder Hornets” in the U.S.: The Rush to Stop the Asian Giant Hornet’
description: In this lesson, you will learn about efforts to stop these insects from establishing colonies in North America — and why these efforts are so important.
content: Featured Article: “‘Murder Hornets’ in the U.S.: The Rush to Stop the Asian Giant Hornet” by Mike Baker
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: What’s Scaring the Pediatricians
description: Children are not the focus of the pandemic. But pediatricians are worried for children and families, for now and for the future.
content: Pediatric patients are not the sickest group right now, or the group most in danger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘My Brilliant Friend’ and ‘Cane River’
description: The season finale of HBO’s Elena Ferrante adaptation. And Horace B. Jenkins’s recently rediscovered film makes its streaming debut.
content: MY BRILLIANT FRIEND 10 p.m. on HBO. Elena and Lila began their lives in the same poor neighborhood of Naples but over the course of two seasons of television their paths have diverged significantly. Elena (Margherita Mazzucco) has put some distance between herself and her humble origins by successfully pursuing education while Lila (Gaia Girace), despite her intelligence and will, remains largely stuck. The distance between the two has complicated but not diminished their deep connection. This season they traveled together to the island of Ischia for vacation. The time away was supposed to help Lila relax enough to get pregnant by her husband but during the sojourn she connected with Nino, a young man that Elena was drawn to first. After the summer, Elena departed Naples for university and Lila eventually returned to her husband.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: If You Have Five Simple Ingredients, You Have This Dutch Baby
description: Stocked up on eggs, milk, butter, flour and salt? Make this weekend-worthy breakfast.
content: The upside of feeling like weekends no longer exist is that, by the same logic, neither do Monday mornings. Which means that making a Dutch baby (also called a German pancake) for breakfast on a weekday is a perfectly reasonable thing to do. Advisable, even.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: With Inflation Ravaging Currency, Iran Is Changing Names and Numbers
description: The rial unit of currency, which has lost much of its value against the dollar, will be replaced by the toman, which the government says will be worth 10,000 rials.
content: For many years, Iran’s government debated changing the national currency, the rial, by basically slashing four zeros off its face value — an acknowledgment of how American sanctions and economic mismanagement have contributed to inflation in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Bremmer, Cliff Kupchan and Scott Rosenstein
title: Coronavirus and the Sweden Myth
description: The country’s approach to the pandemic sets a seductive example. But the United States shouldn’t copy it.
content: For countries battling the coronavirus pandemic, Sweden sets a seductive example. While the world’s biggest economies have shut down, one small, well-governed Scandinavian country has allowed most businesses to stay open. The strategy apparently relies on “herd immunity,” in which a critical mass of infection occurs in lower-risk populations that ultimately thwarts transmission.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Stocks Waver as China Tensions Climb
description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Matthew Abbott
title: In Sydney, the Magic Hour Means Noise. It’s Heavenly to Hear.
description: Five weeks into Australia’s coronavirus lockdown, the sound that bursts forth each afternoon of kids shouting, dogs barking and couples arguing is welcome relief from the quiet of isolation.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — At night, the crickets make my street sound like the wilderness. In the morning, I hear the birds chirping at top volume from sun up until deep into what used to be rush hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Most Events in the Lincoln Memorial Are Banned. Trump Got an Exception.
description: Citing the “extraordinary crisis” of the coronavirus, the interior secretary relaxed the rules so the president could hold a Fox News interview in one of the nation’s most hallowed spaces.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Trump’s aides ran down the list of possible backdrops for his latest Fox News event, they eventually landed on their favorite: the Lincoln Memorial, an iconic tribute to an American life, and one of Mr. Trump’s preferred places to add a prime-time touch of drama to his presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Appeals Court Vacancy Is Under Scrutiny Ahead of Contested Confirmation Hearing
description: The chief judge of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit publicly advanced a call by a progressive group for an ethics investigation into the circumstances of a plum vacancy.
content: Just days before a high-profile Senate confirmation hearing to fill a vacancy on the prestigious U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, the court’s chief judge has opened the door to an inquiry into whether ethical improprieties occurred in the creation of the coveted opening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Senate Office Says It Can’t Release Records Biden Requested
description: Joseph Biden, promising transparency, has asked for any potential records related to a sexual assault allegation against him by Tara Reade to be released. A Senate office says it is legally unable to do so.
content: On Friday, as he forcefully denied an allegation of sexual assault made against him by a former Senate aide, Joseph R. Biden Jr. called on the National Archives to release any complaint related to the accusation.
source.name: The New York Times
